millsfield:images_texts:
5/5/58
Back in 1926 I had an idea that the railroads should be in the
transportation business in all phases. That air travel was coming and
could
be well employed by the railroads to clear their tracks of money-losing
passenger trains in favor of dividend-earning freight. No new rail lines
could be built between, for instance, New York and St. Louis. The expense
of obtaining right-of-way and
construction would be fantastic.
Therefore,
the railroads could meet the increased demand for fast freight only through
clearing their tracks. I talked this idea over with Father and he suggested
that I see his old friend, Alfred H. Smith, President of the New York Central.
I went to New York with a letter of introduction from Father. Mr.
Smith could not have been more courteous. He listened attentively to my
story and
gave me
the
chance to develop my argument fully. I pointed out
that a recent study by the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that 30%
of the time of freight trains and crews in a typical operation was taken up
waiting on sidetracks for passenger trains to pass. I said that the time
would come when the New York Central would say to a prospective passenger,
"We have a passenger train which will take you from New York to St. Louis
in thirty hours. It will be sidetracked along the way so that the fast
freight trains may roll by it. BUT, we have an air service which will take
you from New York to St. Louis in three hours." I then said that for the
present the passenger trains should provide night travel (for in those days,
"fly by night"
was a term applied to people considered a little off the
beam) across the Alleghenys - then known as "the pilot"s graveyard" - with
a change to airplanes for daytime travel over the mid-west flat terrain.
When I had presented all my arguments, Mr. Smith leaned back in
his chair and said: "Young man, the New York Central is not and never will

Page two
be interested in any such crazy scheme. I am surprised that a son of my
old friend, W. K. Bixby, would be so visionary as to believe that anyone would
ever travel as a passenger in an airplane."
After Lindbergh's 1927 goodwill flight around Central America in the
"Spirit of St. Louis", he suggested that we work on my idea of a train by night
and fly by day. We did not see Mr. Smith but rather talked to General Atterbury,
President of the Pennsylvania, who approved the plan, and as a result there
was organized Transcontinental Air Transport. The Pennsylvania provided
overnight service from New York to Columbus, Ohio where the traveler transferred
to a good old tri-motor Ford for the daylight run, and switched to the Atchison,
Topeka and Santa Fe for the second night's run into Los Angel√©s, cutting the
transcontinental train time in two. TAT, unfortunately, is now TWA.
General Atterbury said, "Of course, neither you nor I will ever fly
to St. Louis in three hours, but we may in eight." (My last flight to St.
Louis took two hours and fifty-five minutes! The jets will make it in an
hour and a half.)
Thinking back to my conversation with Mr. Smith of over thirty years
ago, you can imagine that I smiled when I read the following in TIME of May
5, 1958:
"THE
ELEGANCE
DEPARTS"
"In the great age of railroads, one of the symbols of elegance
was the New York Central's Twentieth Century Limited. In the
last 56 years, the Twentieth Century acquired such features as
barbershops, valets, showers, radiotelephone service, gift
corsages, earned about $200 million as the most luxurious

Page three
way of traveling between New York and Chicago. At its
popular peak, the train ran seven sections.
But the
Century's patrons have been gradually defecting to the
airlines. The passengers dwindled from hundreds to as few
as 75 recently, and the Central has lost $1.50 for every
$5. it took in.
This week the Central stripped the
Century of luxury features, combined it with the Commodore
Vanderbilt, added day coaches, made it just another train "for
the summer". But railroaders guessed it would be permanent. "
With all due respect to General Atterbury's favorable attitude toward
the project, it is distinctly an understatement to say that the support of
Charles A. Lindbergh was a whole lot different than my original approach to
Mr. Smith.
After participation by the Pennsylvania, our Government policy pro-
hibited the ownership of air transport undertakings by surface carriers, with
the result that the railroad was compelled to divest itself of its TAT
holdings. The wisdom of that decision at the Government level remains to be
determined. Perhaps if the railroads had been permitted to go full out for
air travel they would today be making good profits instead of losses on pas-
senger business and giving better freight service with increased earnings.
